changes.name: addText
changes.text: Development, Quality Assurance, User Experience & Documentation

changes.name: addText
changes.text: First, make sure your Proxy Settings are set correctly.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Follow the guidelines described in the yellow boxes.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Switch Document Help ON or OFF

changes.name: addText
changes.text: status is the initial conception of a specification.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: A specification with status Standard is considered to be stable and has the approval of the i-Team.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An Obsolete specification is a specification that has been identified unnecessary. For example due to; technology changes or changes in other standards or specifications.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension may require to be configured before it can be used reasonably or in order to adapt it to personal preferences. For example, a spell checker extension could be configured to use different sets of grammar rules, a clock extension could be configured to show twelve or twenty four hours, etc. Configuring the extension should be as easy as possible for the user. That is, a dialog should be used rather then some obscure configuration files which need to be edited. And, of course, this dialog should be easily

changes.name: addText
changes.text: accessible, that is, it needs to be found intuitively.

changes.name: addField

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Give references to any documentation relevant with regards to this specification.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Before writing a specification make sure that the items of the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: State any acronyms and or abbreviations used in this specification in the table below.

changes.name: addField

field.description: What You See Is What You Get

changes.representation: <What You See Is What You Get>

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Future extensions shall be able to integrate own options pages into the options dialog.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An options page is similar to a dialog but is lacking the title bar and border so that

changes.name: addText
changes.text: it can be shown in a parent window, which is the option dialog. The options dialog can also be started from the Extension Manager, in which case it shows only the options pages of the selected extension.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Option pages have to be provided as XDL files together with the corresponding property files. These files

changes.name: addText
changes.text: created with OOo's dialog editor. How this is done is part of the specification for the dialog editor. These files are then used by the com.sun.star.awt.ContainerWindowProvider service, to create an AWT dialog.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The option pages must be suitable for embedding. That is, they may not have a title bar and border. This must be defined at design time in the dialog editor (refer to the dialog editor specification for details). They

changes.name: addText
changes.text: may also not have the “OK”, “CANCEL”, “HELP”, or “Back” buttons. These buttons are already part of OOo's options dialog and the options dialog created by the Extension Manager.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The page size should have the same size as

changes.name: addText
changes.text: viewing area for the options pages in the options dialog.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options dialog will not adapt itself to different sizes.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: can be contained anywhere within the extensions, with the exception of META-INF. Also the properties files which belong to an options page must reside in the same directory as this options page. The URL of the .xdl file

changes.name: addText
changes.text: must be contained in the xcu files which register the options pages in OOo. The URL has the form %origin% + relative path. For example, if the relative path starting from the root directory of the extensions is options/leaf1. Then one provides

changes.name: addText
changes.text: In the Extension Manager dialog, the options dialog can be started through the context menu of an extension. It can also be started by selecting an extension and then press the “Options” button.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: : The entry points to open the options dialog of extensions.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: When an extension does not provide options pages then there will not be a “Options”

changes.name: addText
changes.text: entry in the context menu and the button “Options” will be disabled.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The OOo options dialog is invoked as always.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Options Dialog in the Extension Manager

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options dialog in the Extension Manager is only invoked for exactly one extension. That is, only options pages provided by this extension are shown in the dialog. The exception are options pages for nodes. See chapter

changes.name: addText
changes.text: for details. For example, if an options page shall be displayed under a already existing node, such as “OpenOffice.org Writer”.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options dialog is a modal dialog and has the same layout as OOo's options dialog. The title should contain the display name of the extension. An icon is not displayed.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The title of the options dialog begins with the fixed string 'Options' followed by a blank, a hyphen and a further blank. Then the display name of the extensions follows. If a leaf exists, it's display name will get displayed in

changes.name: addText
changes.text: title too, separated by blank, hyphen and blank from the extension name.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: On the left side is a tree list which shows one or more nodes which can be expanded.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options pages are positioned at the upper left corner of the “

changes.name: addText
changes.text: s pages”, which is the visible area that is available for displaying an options page.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options dialog has a fixed size.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options pages should have a size which fits exactly in the viewing area of the options dialog. If they are too small then empty space is displayed. If they are too large then they are cropped.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The position of the dialog is made persistent. All extensions share this position. For example: the options dialog for extension A

changes.name: addText
changes.text: was closed when it was located at a particular position. Then the options dialog for extension B is invoked and shows up at the same position where it was when it was closed before.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Also the last selected entry is remembered until the office terminates. This information is stored for every single extension that provides options pages. When the user reopens the options dialog for the same extension then the previously selected entry is selected. That is, if this item was a leaf node, then the respective top-level node is expanded, so that the selected entry is shown.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Options Dialog in OOo's Options Dialog

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The options dialog remains the same, except that there may be additional top-level nodes or entries under existing nodes which have been added by extensions

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The elements which make up the data behind the tree view, such as modules, nodes, leaves ,etc., are all defined in the configuration.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: nodes are displayed depends on the module for which the options dialog was invoked or, in other words, from which application it was started.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: A module “knows” which nodes belong to it and only those are displayed.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An options dialog is started on behalf of exactly one module. The module itself is not displayed. Typically the application has a window and in its menu bar there is an entry to invoke the options dialog. For example, when one opens a writer and a spreadsheet document from the backing window, then two windows are open where each one provides for opening the options dialog by way of the Tools | Options ... menu entry. The content of the tree view is not completely the same because the module is different.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The list of modules is not fixed but can be expanded. For example, an extension could provide a new “application” and define a new module for it.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: There are two types of entries in the tree view, such that can be expanded, let's call them “node”, and such that cannot be expanded, which we will call “leaf”. The entries which are visible when no node has been expanded must be all nodes. All entries below a node must be leaves.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: has a human readable localized name and has at least one leaf.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: an options page which is displayed when the node is selected. This options page may not take user input. It is intended to convey information about this node.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: In other words, the same node can appear in the options dialogs of different applications.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: A node is only displayed if it

changes.name: addText
changes.text: is assigned to a module which is the same as the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: module on which behalf the options dialog was started. A node may be assigned to one or many modules.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The list of nodes can be extended by new nodes. For example, extension may define new nodes.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: product nodes (StarOffice, OpenOffice.org) which are related to a particular product. For example OpenOffice.org, OpenOffice.org Writer, etc. These names are created at runtime and the static node name only contains the place holder %PRODUCTNAME.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: To avoid further complexity we will not provide general mechanism to have alias nodes dependent on a “product context”.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: A leaf has a human readable, localized name. Every leaf has exactly one options page and is assigned to exactly one node. A leaf

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Leaves also have a unique identifier (chapter

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Leaves can be added , for example by extensions. They can be assigned to already existing nodes or nodes which have been added by the same extension.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Modules, nodes, and leaves have an unique identifier. These are used as values for the oor:name attributes of a node element in the xcu file. Other identifiers are used as property values in the xcu files. All these identifiers have to comply to the requirements for node names and value elements off

changes.name: addText
changes.text: To ensure uniqueness, we recommend to form the strings similar to this schema:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Identifier identity is element-by-element identity of the sequences of Unicode scalar values (no case folding, no normalization, etc.).

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Because modules, nodes and leaves can be provided by different parties (including OOo) which also could reuse existing modules and nodes one has to take care when removing them in order to not corrupting the data. It follow special use cases and the solution.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension defines a new node. Another extension may use this node to

changes.name: addText
changes.text: its own leaves. Now the first extension is uninstalled along with its configuration data including the definition for the node. Then the leaves of the other extension refer to a non – existing node.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Solution: Currently nodes defined by an extension may not be assigned to modules of another extension and leaves provided by an extension may not be assigned

changes.name: addText
changes.text: to nodes which have been defined by another

changes.name: addText
changes.text: extension. This rule may be revoked when extensions can define dependencies to other dependencies.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension defines a new node. OOo assigns leaves to this node. If the extension is uninstalled then there is no relation between the node and the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Solution: Nodes defined by OOo may not be assigned to modules

changes.name: addText
changes.text: defined by extensions and leaves defined by OOo may not be assigned to nodes which have been defined by extensions.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: OOo defines a new node. Extension may provide leaves which are assigned to this node. In a later version of OOo the node would

changes.name: addText
changes.text: be removed. Then there is no relation between the node and the leaves anymore.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Solution: Open issue. This is a very rare case. It is up to the implementation to handle this gracefully.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension uses a node of OOo but when it is installed this version of OOo does not provide this node.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Solution: Open issue. This is a very rare case. It is up to the implementation to handle this gracefully.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Configuration data has been added through the Extension Manager which defines a new node. The configuration was contained in single xcu and xcs files, that is, the data was not part of an extension. The node could then be used by OOo or other extensions. If the configuration data would be removed later if would leave behind leaves referencing

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Solution: Modules and nodes may not be defined by configuration data which has been added as single files by

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Extension Manager. Those files must be put into extensions. Then the solution for #1applies.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: When one provides a definition for a node together with definitions for leaves then one would like to determine the order of the leaves. Similarly this is valid for modules and nodes. This can be achieved by using indices for

changes.name: addText
changes.text: nodes and leaves. Because extensions can add nodes and leaves to already existing modules and nodes, it could happen that

changes.name: addText
changes.text: the same index is used multiple times. To prevent this, we determine that the index used by nodes and leaves, which are added to an existing module or node, applies only within this group of nodes or leaves. That is, the elements of the group are ordered according to the index but the absolute position cannot be determined. Therefore the index used by a group does not interfere

changes.name: addText
changes.text: with the index used by modules and nodes.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The illustration shows that it can be determined that Leaf 1 of Extension A and Leaf 2 of Extensions A are grouped together and in this order but the extensions cannot

changes.name: addText
changes.text: determine if the leaves of extension B show up before or after those of extension A.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: In the Extension Manager the options dialog can be invoked on behalf of an extensions. That is, the options dialog shows only options pages provided by

changes.name: addText
changes.text: respective extension. If the options pages uses a node which has not been defined by the same extension then this node and the corresponding options page are displayed as well. For example, if an extension provides an options page which will be shown under OpenOffice.org Writer then this node is also displayed when the options dialog was invoked from the Extension Manager.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Contrary to OOo's options dialog the module is not used. That is, all nodes are displayed no matter what the module is. This includes also nodes which refer to applications which are in a separate module but which are currently not installed.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: A node can be part of different modules. Then these nodes are displayed only once. For example, an extension defines two modules, module1 an module2, and three nodes which relate to these modules. The following illustration shows the relationship:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The next illustrations shows how the nodes could be displayed. Because it is not defined which nodes of which module are displayed first, different representations are possible.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: : Example: Possible representation in options dialog 1

changes.name: addText
changes.text: In the next illustration the nodes of module2 are displayed first, followed by those of module1. Because Node 1 and Node 3 are already displayed only Node 2 needs to be added.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: : Example: Possible representation in options dialog 2

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Publishing Information for the Options Dialog

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension needs to provide configuration data (xcu files) in order to define modules, nodes and leaves. These files can be anywhere in the extension, except in META-INF, and there must be an appropriate entry in the manifest-xml.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Event handler for the various UI element in the options page can be provided by the extension. These have to be suitable for use with the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: XContainerWindowProvider.createContainerWindow function and must implement the interface com.sun.star.awt.XContainerWindowEventHandler. The handlers must be implemented in one service which is registered during installation of the extension (entry in manifest.xml) and there must be a configuration entry which identifies this service as handler for this particular options page.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The buttons OK, Cancel, Help, Back are not part of the options pages. But pressing these buttons will cause the handler to be called. Then the method string will be “external_event” and the event object will contain a string containing the actual command.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: To determine for what options page the event is intended one can determine the name property of the dialog, which is passed as argument to the method XContainerWindowEventHandler.callHandlerMethod.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: There will be currently no events for Cancel and Help.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The OK button causes a notification on behalf of all pages, no matter if they are currently displayed or not. Whereas the Back button causes only a notification on behalf of the currently visible options page. The following table summarizes this.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Notify for currently displayed options page

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Method string in the event object

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Initialization means loading the last used values and set them into the respective controls in the options page. This happens when an options pange is being displayed. Initialization is triggered by a call to XContainerWindowEventHandler.callHandlerMethod and passing the method string “external_event” and the event object contains the string “ initialize”.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Because the Extension Manager uses a non - modal dialog, it is possible that OOo's options dialog and the Extension Manager's options dialog are open at the same time. Both dialogs use the same location to save and read the options - data. If now both dialogs are open and both change the data, then the dialog that is closed last will overwrite the changes made by the other.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Implementing a synchronization mechanism, would add more complexity to the implementation of OOo and the extensions.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Since this is a very special case which will only affect a very minimum of users, we will not offer a framework in OOo. However, extensions are free to implement a synchronization mechanism. This is possible because they read and write the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Using OOo's Registry for Options Data

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Settings made by users need to be saved. A possible location is the OOo's registry. The Extension Manager will not provide an automatism for this task. Instead the extension must provide an appropriate service (see chapter

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Setting done by a user only apply to this user. If the extension provides configuration data (.xcu files) then this data is used as default by all users. Once a user modifies a setting, the new value only applies for this user. Other users still see the default values unless they have already modified them.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The Extension Manager will not offer a way to modify settings for all users by a single person.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The configuration data of an extension can be reused when another version of this extension is installed. This only refers to data which have been modified by the user and hence has been written into the user layer of the configuration. If a user did not modify the data, then the configuration data of the new extension is used. Of course, this also depends on other existing configuration layers. That is, the options page may show different values, although the user never changed the settings and in the xcu file of extension are other values.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: new version of an extension is installed and is has the same configuration schema then the modified settings of the previous version of the extension are used. This also applies if an extension is replaced by an older version.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Note: This currently works since the modified data remains in the user layer even if the corresponding schema and data files have been removed.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: If one does not want that a new version uses settings from the previously installed version then the extension must provide a new schema. .

changes.name: addText
changes.text: in the configuration which point to data and it is the intention of the developers that the data is reused, then they must not use URLs which point into installation directory of the extension. The reason is that the extension update installs the new version into a different directory. That is, URL may be invalid after an update.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Extension does not use the Configuration

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension need not use necessarily the configuration to store its configuration data. It could write the user data somewhere else, for example to $HOME, etc. It is then up to the developer to define how the data is modified depending on whether the extension is installed as user, shared extensions or both.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The Same Extension Installed as Shared and User Extension

changes.name: addText
changes.text: If the same extension, or different versions of it, is installed as user and shared extension, then the Extension Manager shows only the options dialog for the user extension.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Reasoning: Provided that both extensions use the same configuration schema, then changes in the options dialog will be saved in the same configuration data. That is, changes made to the options of one extension overwrite the settings made in the options dialog of the other. If the configuration data contain URLs with %origin%, and the URL is expanded then it points into the directory of the user extension. This is important, when different versions are installed and the data referenced by the URL is different. When the values change in different versions of the extension, then the user may see inconsistent default values in the options dialog. For example, data item “A” has the value “a” and was installed by a shared extension. Now a newer version is installed as user extension and this extension defines that data item “A” has the value “b”. When one opened the options dialog for the shared extension then one would see value “b” instead of “a”, which was the case before the user extension was installed. After uninstalling the user extension the options dialog would again show value “a”. This behavior occurs only if the user has not yet modified “A”. Then the modified value would be shown in either case.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The OOo's options dialog displays the options pages for the user installation only.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Important: Because a extension can be installed as shared and user extension and also because modified data remains in the user layer of the configuration, the configuration schema must not change incompatibly. This would lead to unexpected behavior at runtime.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: An extension should bring sensible default values for its options dialog settings. In some cases the user needs to provide settings before the extension can be used. In this case it is up to the extension code to point this out to the user. Since the setting can be scattered over several nodes in the options dialog and also it is not necessarily recognizable which settings are mandatory it is recommended that the extension provides a wizard for the user.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Extensions can bring help texts for their options pages

changes.name: addText
changes.text: which will be integrated into the help system at deploy time. The mechanism used to display them is the same as when showing ordinary dialogs. There is nothing to be done.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Bear in mind the following rules when writing a specification:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: ] First and foremost a specification has to be complete. That means all relevant aspects of a feature have to be captured.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: OpenOffice.org User Interface Text Style Guide

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Do designs meet the requirements of the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Do alerts meet the requirements specified in the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Are all menu related changes specified in the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Are all tool bar related changes specified in the

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Is each UI element specified in detail (e.g. default values, input and output ranges, interactions and possible relations to other UI elements and parts of the UI)?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Is the exception handling specified in detail?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Is the specification clear enough to the intended readership for being implemented,

changes.name: addText
changes.text: being tested and for being documented?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Are you using quantifiable statements instead of interpretable generalities? For instance: Have you avoided to use terms like

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Are you consistent within the specification and to specifications which relate to the feature you are specifying?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: ] Each statement shall be as short and simple as possible.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Is any secondary writing regarding the detailed specification clearly separated e.g.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Use graphics when concepts, designs, or processes are too complex or cumbersome

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Specify the user interface precisely. Add mock-ups of all user interface screens to illustrate the general “look & feel”. Each mock-up has to provide:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: A caption providing a figure number and a short description of what is displayed in the mock-up.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: : Shows a mock-up of an fictive Insert Footnote dialog

changes.name: addField

field.description: If this part is irrelevant state a reason for  its absence!

changes.representation: <Start typing here ----- If this part is irrelevant state a reason for  its absence!>

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Describe in this section the migration path. For example, if changes introduces a new functionality which is not covered by older versions of the product. Check:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Did I specify the incompatible or removed configuration settings?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Did I specify all newly needed, or removed files, modules?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Did I specify how users are affected by this change?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The schema can be found at

changes.name: addText
changes.text: It defines the sets Modules and Nodes under <component> which use template types which are defined in the same file.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: If a setting (this includes also user interface settings) has to be stored in the configuration check the following:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Did I state the default, where setting has to be stored (configuration path)?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Did I specify which data type it is?

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Did I specify when the setting is activate (restart of application, for all new documents/windows after the change, or also for all opened documents/windows)

changes.name: addText
changes.text: If it is a new / incompatible setting did I specify a migration path?

changes.name: addField

field.description: If this part is irrelevant state a reason for  its absence!

changes.representation: <Start typing here ----- If this part is irrelevant state a reason for  its absence!>

changes.name: addText
changes.text: If this functionality changes the file format it has to be described here:

changes.name: addText
changes.text: which elements, attributes or/and properties are affected,

changes.name: addText
changes.text: how it will affect older revisions of the file format

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Export/Import-transformation to older revisions, if incompatible changes are needed

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Modification of Settings for All Users (Shared Extensions)

changes.name: addText
changes.text: for changing configuration data by an administrator is by using APOC. Managing extension by APOC requires some changes to APOC configuration. Please refer to the APOC documentation for further explanations.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: com.sun.star.configuration.AdministrationProvider which could be used for changing shared configuration data is currently not functional.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: If we used this service then we would need to change the UI so that the user can switch between making settings for all users and

changes.name: addText
changes.text: making settings for himself where both settings apply for shared extensions.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Currently the modified data remains in the user layer of the configuration even if the extension, including the xcu and xcs files is uninstalled. That is, the new version of the extension automatically uses the modified data unless it uses a different schema. It would be reasonable to allow to remove data in the user layer for data which has been defined by the extension. Then an extension could define in its description.xml if it want to reuse the data and could also specify the versions of the extensions from which it would reuse the data.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: This would make it necessary to extract exactly the values which have been modified by the user. This happens before the extension is uninstalled. When the new version is installed then the previously extracted data is restored in the configuration. However, this is very difficult or maybe impossible to achieve with the current configuration, because it merges different layers to obtain one view on the data.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: The settings in the options dialog are only one example for the use of configuration data. One could imagine to extend the reuse of configuration data to all possible data used by an extension, no matter if it is used for the options dialog or not. And one could imagine, that one could specify in the description.xml exactly nodes of the data which are to be reused.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Since the configuration schema and data used by an extension may change between different versions of the extension one could also think of a mechanism for data migration. For example, we could define a particular migration service which the extension has to provide. This service could be run after the version has been installed.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Removing Nodes and Modules in OOo

changes.name: addText
changes.text: For reasons of time, we will postpone the migration of the existing entries until further notice.

changes.name: addText
changes.text: Questions and unsolved will arise during the creation process of the specification. Make sure that no open issue are left, when the specification gets the state “Standard”

changes.name: addField

field.description: State Issue here, State  “None”, if all issues are solved
